items.content_html:
"Last-Modified" is not a response header, actually is a Entity header.
Source: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc2616#section-14.29

Summary

I changed the word "response" for the word "Entity".

Motivation

Because it's wrong, doesn't correspond with rfc2616 documentation.

Supporting details

https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc2616#section-14.29

Related issues

items.content_html:
Updated description on event loop

Summary

Changed content of html_dom_api/microtask_guide doc, in order to fix wrong description on event loop and task.

Motivation

As mentioned in #11840, current description seems to provide incorrect description.
This PR will fix it.

Supporting details

The decription in the following MDN doc describes event loop to perform one task per iteration.
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/EventLoop#stack
This PR will make "microtask guide" doc to be coherent to "event loop" doc.
For more explanation including html spec doc, please refer to #11840

Related issues

#11840

items.content_html:
Summary

Since finally blocks always execute, there is some nuance with the generator's return method
when the generator is suspended within a try...finally statement.

Motivation

This came from me tinkering with generators with try...finally and wondering what happened to the value I provided to return. The pattern of using try/catch/finally in a generator is great for cancelation patterns, but I stopped at documenting the interaction. What patterns are possible can be left as an exercise for the reader.

Supporting details

Here's a repl.it link of this example for convenience: https://replit.com/@DingoEatingFuzz/GeneratorReturn#index.js

Related issues

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Adds a generator#return example that includes try...finally

If the form to send has an input that doesn't have a type attribute, the script stops.

If the form to send has an input that doesn't have a type attribute, the script stops.
For example:

items.content_html:
Part of #10337.

What's currently done here is a rewrite of the first four parts of the JS Objects module. What's not done is any updates to the "test your skills" bits, or any of the other pages in this module. But I think they are either going to be quite minor or it will be clear what to do about them once we've decided how to present these first four parts.

The current module begins with the following four parts:

  • Object basics: describes object literals and walks through stuff about accessing and modifying members, and a bit about this. Pretty inoffensive.

  • Object-oriented JavaScript for beginners: starts off going through some conceptual OOP stuff, which is mostly OK though I had issues with some of it - I think headings should reflect real terminology (i.e. use "inheritance" rather than "Specialist classes") and I didn't like the way the diagrams for class/instance and for inheritance looked almost identical though they are very different things. It then talks about JS constructors, which was mostly OK but seemed like a bit of a non-sequitur.

  • Object prototypes: this tallked about prototypes and the prototype chain, then got into how to use prototypes to implement class-based inheritance. I must say I found this extremely hard going, right from the start! I'm not sure how beginners could follow this.

  • Inheritance in JavaScript: this continued where the last article left off and then half way through switched into class syntax and showed the (much simpler) way to do it there.

One thing I wanted to avoid was the suggestion that prototypes are basically just a crap way of doing OOP in JS, that's all fixed by class. The problem is if you just present prototypes as a way of implementing class-based OOP, then it will tend to end up like this. I think that gives a false impression, as there are things prototypes are useful for, that are not class-based OOP (for example, you can see them as a delegation system more than an inheritance system).

So at a high level I wanted to separate out discussion of prototypes in JS from discussion of implementing class-based OOP in JS. I think that if you want to do class-based OOP in JS, then class is really helpful. But class-based OOP is not at all the only way you can combine objects in JS, and sometimes (maybe often) something more lightweight is better. Although I didn't want to go into those alternatives, I at least wanted to leave that open.

So I have:

  • Object basics: starts out like the current one but then talks about constructors. Note that we haven't talked about OOP yet, so this is just constructors in themselves, as a useful way to create object instances. I am conflicted about whether to make the constructors bit into its own article. That would make it easier to refer to, but it would be pretty short.

  • Object prototypes: explains what prototypes are, and how the chain works, and how to set your own prototypes. Again, no OOP yet, so this is just prototypes as themselves, not as a means to implementing any system. But a bit at the end about how they might relate to inheritance.

  • Object-oriented programming: mostly just conceptual stuff about class-based OOP: classes versus instances, inheritance, encapsulation. Then at the end I've tried to tie that to prototypes, and tried to be careful about how the prototype model is similar, how it is different, and how if you want to write class-based OOP in JS, there is this class stuff you should look at rather than trying to build it directly using prototypes.

  • Classes in JavaScript: this just presents class and so on, and is very straightforward. I didn't cover everything here - maybe I should include static, and getters/setters?

At this point I'm mostly interested in general feedback about whether this is a good way to present things overall. If we agree it is, I'll update all the other bits in this module and ask for a full review. (That is, I'm happy to accept detailed feedback now, but will ask for a full review eventually anyway).
items.title: JS Learning Area Objects module updates

items.content_html:
Summary

This PR adds the required documentation for the WindowControlsOverlay JS API.

Motivation

Desktop-installed PWAs can now use the Window Controls Overlay feature (available generally starting from Chrome/Edge 98).

Using this feature requires using the window-controls-overlay display mode in the display_override member, which was already documented here: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Manifest/display_override

And the feature also relies on new CSS environment variables (titlebar-area-*) which were also already documented here: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/env()#using_env_to_ensure_content_is_not_obscured_by_window_control_buttons_in_desktop_pwas

The remaining piece for this feature is a JavaScript API: navigator.windowControlsOverlay which I am documenting in this PR.
The API isn't very complicated, it has just one property (visible), one event handler (ongeometrychange), and one method (getTitlebarAreaRect).

I believe I have made all of the necessary changes for these things to be documented.

Notes

  • I did not create a separate interface reference page for the WindowControlsOverlayGeometryChangeEvent. This event is (for now) simple enough that I documented its properties in the event page, instead of creating another one for the interface.
  • The version of BCD currently in use needs to be updated to fix the current BCD errors. I am adding the necessary compat data in the BCD repo here: mdn/browser-compat-data#14095.

Related issues

This is part of this content proposal parent issue: #10539

items.title: Reference documentation for the Window Controls Overlay API
